  • Changelog

survstan

The R package survstan can be used to fit right-censored survival data under independent censoring. The implemented models allow the fitting of survival data in the presence/absence of covariates. All inferential procedures are currently based on the maximum likelihood (ML) approach.

Installation

You can install the released version of survstan from CRAN with:

install.packages("survstan")

You can install the development version of survstan from GitHub with:

# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("fndemarqui/survstan")

Inference procedures

Let (ti,Î´i)(t_{i}, \delta_{i}) be the observed survival time and its corresponding failure indicator, i=1,â‹¯,ni=1, \cdots, n, and ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta} be a kÃ—1k \times 1 vector of parameters. Then, the likelihood function for right-censored survival data under independent censoring can be expressed as:

L(ğ›‰)=âˆi=1nf(ti|ğ›‰)Î´iS(ti|ğ›‰)1âˆ’Î´i. L(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}f(t_{i}|\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\delta_{i}}S(t_{i}|\boldsymbol{\theta})^{1-\delta_{i}}.

The maximum likelihood estimate (MLE) of ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta} is obtained by directly maximization of log(L(ğ›‰))\log(L(\boldsymbol{\theta})) using the rstan::optimizing() function. The function rstan::optimizing() further provides the hessian matrix of log(L(ğ›‰))\log(L(\boldsymbol{\theta})), needed to obtain the observed Fisher information matrix, which is given by:

â„(ğ›‰Ì‚)=âˆ’âˆ‚2âˆ‚ğ›‰ğ›‰â€²logL(ğ›‰)âˆ£ğ›‰=ğ›‰Ì‚, \mathscr{I}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}) = -\frac{\partial^2}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}\boldsymbol{\theta}'} \log L(\boldsymbol{\theta})\mid_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}},

Inferences on ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta} are then based on the asymptotic properties of the MLE, ğ›‰Ì‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}, that state that:

ğ›‰Ì‚â‰Nk(ğ›‰,â„âˆ’1(ğ›‰Ì‚)). \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \asymp N_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \mathscr{I}^{-1}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})).

Baseline Distributions

Some of the most popular baseline survival distributions are implemented in the R package survstan. Such distributions include:

  • Exponential
  • Weibull
  • Lognormal
  • Loglogistic
  • Gamma,
  • Generalized Gamma (original Stacyâ€™s parametrization)
  • Generalized Gamma (alternative Prenticeâ€™s parametrization)
  • Gompertz
  • Rayleigh
  • Birnbaum-Saunders (fatigue)

The parametrizations adopted in the package survstan are presented next.

Exponential Distribution

If Tâˆ¼Exp(Î»)T \sim \mbox{Exp}(\lambda), then

f(t|Î»)=Î»exp{âˆ’Î»t}I[0,âˆ)(t), f(t|\lambda) = \lambda\exp\left\{-\lambda t\right\}I_{[0, \infty)}(t), where Î»>0\lambda>0 is the rate parameter.

The survival and hazard functions in this case are given by:

S(t|Î»)=exp{âˆ’Î»t} S(t|\lambda) = \exp\left\{-\lambda t\right\} and h(t|Î»)=Î». h(t|\lambda) = \lambda.

Weibull Distribution

If Tâˆ¼Weibull(Î±,Î³)T \sim \mbox{Weibull}(\alpha, \gamma), then

f(t|Î±,Î³)=Î±Î³Î±tÎ±âˆ’1exp{âˆ’(tÎ³)Î±}I[0,âˆ)(t), f(t|\alpha, \gamma) = \frac{\alpha}{\gamma^{\alpha}}t^{\alpha-1}\exp\left\{-\left(\frac{t}{\gamma}\right)^{\alpha}\right\}I_{[0, \infty)}(t), where Î±>0\alpha>0 and Î³>0\gamma>0 are the shape and scale parameters, respectively.

The survival and hazard functions in this case are given by:

S(t|Î±,Î³)=exp{âˆ’(tÎ³)Î±} S(t|\alpha, \gamma) = \exp\left\{-\left(\frac{t}{\gamma}\right)^{\alpha}\right\} and h(t|Î±,Î³)=Î±Î³Î±tÎ±âˆ’1. h(t|\alpha, \gamma) = \frac{\alpha}{\gamma^{\alpha}}t^{\alpha-1}.

Lognormal Distribution

If Tâˆ¼LN(Î¼,Ïƒ)T \sim \mbox{LN}(\mu, \sigma), then

f(t|Î¼,Ïƒ)=12Ï€tÏƒexp{âˆ’12(log(t)âˆ’Î¼Ïƒ)2}I[0,âˆ)(t), f(t|\mu, \sigma) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}t\sigma}\exp\left\{-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{log(t)-\mu}{\sigma}\right)^2\right\}I_{[0, \infty)}(t), where âˆ’âˆ<Î¼<âˆ-\infty < \mu < \infty and Ïƒ>0\sigma>0 are the mean and standard deviation in the log scale of TT.

The survival and hazard functions in this case are given by:

S(t|Î¼,Ïƒ)=Î¦(âˆ’log(t)+Î¼Ïƒ)S(t|\mu, \sigma) = \Phi\left(\frac{-log(t)+\mu}{\sigma}\right) and h(t|Î¼,Ïƒ)=f(t|Î¼,Ïƒ)S(t|Î¼,Ïƒ),h(t|\mu, \sigma) = \frac{f(t|\mu, \sigma)}{S(t|\mu, \sigma)}, where Î¦(â‹…)\Phi(\cdot) is the cumulative distribution function of the standard normal distribution.

Loglogistic Distribution

If Tâˆ¼LL(Î±,Î³)T \sim \mbox{LL}(\alpha, \gamma), then

f(t|Î±,Î³)=Î±Î³(tÎ³)Î±âˆ’1[1+(tÎ³)Î±]2I[0,âˆ)(t),Î±>0,Î³>0, f(t|\alpha, \gamma) = \frac{\frac{\alpha}{\gamma}\left(\frac{t}{\gamma}\right)^{\alpha-1}}{\left[1 + \left(\frac{t}{\gamma}\right)^{\alpha}\right]^2}I_{[0, \infty)}(t), ~ \alpha>0, \gamma>0,

where Î±>0\alpha>0 and Î³>0\gamma>0 are the shape and scale parameters, respectively.

The survival and hazard functions in this case are given by:

S(t|Î±,Î³)=11+(tÎ³)Î±S(t|\alpha, \gamma) = \frac{1}{1+ \left(\frac{t}{\gamma}\right)^{\alpha}} and h(t|Î±,Î³)=Î±Î³(tÎ³)Î±âˆ’11+(tÎ³)Î±. h(t|\alpha, \gamma) = \frac{\frac{\alpha}{\gamma}\left(\frac{t}{\gamma}\right)^{\alpha-1}}{1 + \left(\frac{t}{\gamma}\right)^{\alpha}}.

Gamma Distribution

If Tâˆ¼Gamma(Î±,Î»)T \sim \mbox{Gamma}(\alpha, \lambda), then

f(t|Î±,Î»)=Î»Î±Î“(Î±)tÎ±âˆ’1exp{âˆ’Î»t}I[0,âˆ)(t),f(t|\alpha, \lambda) = \frac{\lambda^{\alpha}}{\Gamma(\alpha)}t^{\alpha-1}\exp\left\{-\lambda t\right\}I_{[0, \infty)}(t),

where Î“(Î±)=âˆ«0âˆuÎ±âˆ’1exp{âˆ’u}du\Gamma(\alpha) = \int_{0}^{\infty}u^{\alpha-1}\exp\{-u\}du is the gamma function.

The survival function is given by

S(t|Î±,Î»)=1âˆ’Î³*(Î±,Î»t)Î“(Î±),S(t|\alpha, \lambda) = 1 - \frac{\gamma^{*}(\alpha, \lambda t)}{\Gamma(\alpha)}, where Î³*(Î±,Î»t)\gamma^{*}(\alpha, \lambda t) is the lower incomplete gamma function, which is available only numerically. Finally, the hazard function is expressed as:

h(t|Î±,Î»)=f(t|Î±,Î»)S(t|Î±,Î»).h(t|\alpha, \lambda) = \frac{f(t|\alpha, \lambda)}{S(t|\alpha, \lambda)}.

Generalized Gamma Distribution (original Stacyâ€™s parametrization)

If Tâˆ¼ggstacy(Î±,Î³,Îº)T \sim \mbox{ggstacy}(\alpha, \gamma, \kappa), then

f(t|Î±,Î³,Îº)=ÎºÎ³Î±Î“(Î±/Îº)tÎ±âˆ’1exp{âˆ’(tÎ³)Îº}I[0,âˆ)(t),f(t|\alpha, \gamma, \kappa) = \frac{\kappa}{\gamma^{\alpha}\Gamma(\alpha/\kappa)}t^{\alpha-1}\exp\left\{-\left(\frac{t}{\gamma}\right)^{\kappa}\right\}I_{[0, \infty)}(t), for Î±>0\alpha>0, Î³>0\gamma>0 and Îº>0\kappa>0.

It can be show that the survival function can be expressed as:

S(t|Î±,Î³,Îº)=SG(x|Î½,1),S(t|\alpha, \gamma, \kappa) = S_{G}(x|\nu, 1), where x=(tÎ³)Îºx = \displaystyle\left(\frac{t}{\gamma}\right)^\kappa, and FG(â‹…|Î½,1)F_{G}(\cdot|\nu, 1) corresponds to the distribution function of a gamma distribution with shape parameter Î½=Î±/Î³\nu = \alpha/\gamma and scale parameter equals to 1.

Finally, the hazard function is expressed as:

h(t|Î±,Î³,Îº)=f(t|Î±,Î³,Îº)S(t|Î±,Î³,Îº).h(t|\alpha, \gamma, \kappa) = \frac{f(t|\alpha, \gamma, \kappa)}{S(t|\alpha, \gamma, \kappa)}.

Generalized Gamma Distribution (alternative Prenticeâ€™s parametrization)

If Tâˆ¼ggprentice(Î¼,Ïƒ,Ï†)T \sim \mbox{ggprentice}(\mu, \sigma, \varphi), then

f(t|Î¼,Ïƒ,Ï†)={|Ï†|(Ï†âˆ’2)Ï†âˆ’2ÏƒtÎ“(Ï†âˆ’2)exp{Ï†âˆ’2[Ï†wâˆ’exp(Ï†w)]}I[0,âˆ)(t),Ï†â‰ 012Ï€tÏƒexp{âˆ’12(log(t)âˆ’Î¼Ïƒ)2}I[0,âˆ)(t),Ï†=0f(t | \mu, \sigma, \varphi) = \begin{cases} \frac{|\varphi|(\varphi^{-2})^{\varphi^{-2}}}{\sigma t\Gamma(\varphi^{-2})}\exp\{\varphi^{-2}[\varphi w - \exp(\varphi w)]\}I_{[0, \infty)}(t), & \varphi \neq 0 \\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}t\sigma}\exp\left\{-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{log(t)-\mu}{\sigma}\right)^2\right\}I_{[0, \infty)}(t), & \varphi = 0 \end{cases} where w=log(t)âˆ’Î¼Ïƒw = \frac{\log(t) - \mu}{\sigma}, for âˆ’âˆ<Î¼<âˆ-\infty < \mu < \infty, Ïƒ>0\sigma>0 and âˆ’âˆ<Ï†<âˆ-\infty < \varphi < \infty$.

It can be show that the survival function can be expressed as:

S(t|Î¼,Ïƒ,Ï†)={SG(x|1/Ï†2,1),Ï†>01âˆ’SG(x|1/Ï†2,1),Ï†<0SLN(x|Î¼,Ïƒ),Ï†=0 S(t|\mu, \sigma, \varphi) = \begin{cases} S_{G}(x|1/\varphi^2, 1), & \varphi > 0 \\ 1-S_{G}(x|1/\varphi^2, 1), & \varphi < 0 \\ S_{LN}(x|\mu, \sigma), & \varphi = 0 \end{cases} where x=1Ï†2exp{Ï†w}x = \frac{1}{\varphi^2}\exp\{\varphi w\}, SG(â‹…|1/Ï†2,1)S_{G}(\cdot|1/\varphi^2, 1) is the distribution function of a gamma distribution with shape parameter 1/Ï†21/\varphi^2 and scale parameter equals to 1, and SLN(x|Î¼,Ïƒ)S_{LN}(x|\mu, \sigma) corresponds to the survival function of a lognormal distribution with location parameter Î¼\mu and scale parameter Ïƒ\sigma.

Finally, the hazard function is expressed as:

h(t|Î±,Î³,Îº)=f(t|Î±,Î³,Îº)S(t|Î±,Î³,Îº).h(t|\alpha, \gamma, \kappa) = \frac{f(t|\alpha, \gamma, \kappa)}{S(t|\alpha, \gamma, \kappa)}.

Gompertz Distribution

If Tâˆ¼Gamma(Î±,Î³)T \sim \mbox{Gamma}(\alpha, \gamma), then

f(t|Î±,Î»)=Î±exp{Î³xâˆ’Î±Î³(eÎ³xâˆ’1)}I[0,âˆ)(t).f(t|\alpha, \lambda) = \alpha\exp\left\{\gamma x-\frac{\alpha}{\gamma}\left(e^{\gamma x} - 1\right)\right\}I_{[0, \infty)}(t).

The survival and hazard functions are given, respectively, by

S(t|Î±,Î»)=exp{âˆ’Î±Î³(eÎ³xâˆ’1)}.S(t|\alpha, \lambda) = \exp\left\{-\frac{\alpha}{\gamma}\left(e^{\gamma x} - 1\right)\right\}. and

$$h(t|\alpha, \lambda) = \alpha\exp\{\gamma x}.$$

Rayleigh Distribution

Let Tâˆ¼rayleigh(Ïƒ)T \sim \mbox{rayleigh}(\sigma), where Ïƒ>0\sigma>0 is a scale parameter. Then, the density, survival and hazard functions are respectively given by:

f(t|Ïƒ)=xÏƒ2exp{âˆ’x22Ïƒ2},f(t|\sigma) = \frac{x}{\sigma^2}\exp\left\{-\frac{x^2}{2\sigma^2}\right\},S(t|Ïƒ)=exp{âˆ’x22Ïƒ2}S(t|\sigma) = \exp\left\{-\frac{x^2}{2\sigma^2}\right\} and

h(t|Ïƒ)=xÏƒ2.h(t|\sigma) = \frac{x}{\sigma^2}.

Birnbaum-Saunders (fatigue) Distribution

If Tâˆ¼fatigue(Î±,Î³)T \sim \mbox{fatigue}(\alpha, \gamma), then

f(t|Î±,Î³)=tÎ³+Î³t2Î±tÏ•(tÎ³+Î³t)(t),Î±>0,Î³>0, f(t|\alpha, \gamma) = \frac{\sqrt{\frac{t}{\gamma}}+\sqrt{\frac{\gamma}{t}}}{2 \alpha t}\phi\left(\sqrt{\frac{t}{\gamma}}+\sqrt{\frac{\gamma}{t}}\right)(t), ~ \alpha>0, \gamma>0,

where Ï•(â‹…)\phi(\cdot) is the probability density function of a standard normal distribution, Î±>0\alpha>0 and Î³>0\gamma>0 are the shape and scale parameters, respectively.

The survival function in this case is given by:

S(t|Î±,Î³)=Î¦(tÎ³âˆ’Î³t)(t) S(t|\alpha, \gamma) =\Phi\left(\sqrt{\frac{t}{\gamma}}-\sqrt{\frac{\gamma}{t}}\right)(t) ,

where Î¦(â‹…)\Phi(\cdot) is the cumulative distribution function of a standard normal distribution. The hazard function is given by h(t|Î¼,Ïƒ)=f(t|Î±,Î³)S(t|Î±,Î³).h(t|\mu, \sigma) = \frac{f(t|\alpha, \gamma)}{S(t|\alpha, \gamma)}.

Regression models

When covariates are available, it is possible to fit six different regression models with the R package survstan:

  • accelerated failure time (AFT) models;
  • proportional hazards (PH) models;
  • proportional odds (PO) models;
  • accelerated hazard (AH) models.
  • Yang and Prentice (YP) models.
  • extended hazard (EH) models.

The regression survival models implemented in the R package survstan are briefly described in the sequel. Denote by ğ±\mathbf{x} a 1Ã—p1\times p vector of covariates, and let ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta} and ğ›Ÿ\boldsymbol{\phi} be pÃ—1p \times 1 vectors of regression coefficients, and ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta} a vector of parameters associated with some baseline survival distribution. To prevent identifiability issues, it is assumed that the linear predictors ğ±ğ›ƒ\mathbf{x} \boldsymbol{\beta} and ğ±ğ›Ÿ\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\phi} do not include an intercept term.

Accelerate Failure Time Models

Accelerated failure time (AFT) models are defined as

T=exp{ğ±ğ›ƒ}Î½, T = \exp\{\mathbf{x} \boldsymbol{\beta}\}\nu, where Î½\nu follows a baseline distribution with survival function S0(â‹…|ğ›‰)S_{0}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}) so that

f(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ±)=eâˆ’ğ±ğ›ƒf0(teâˆ’ğ±ğ›ƒ|ğ›‰) f(t|\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\beta}, \mathbf{x}) = e^{-\mathbf{x} \boldsymbol{\beta}}f_{0}(te^{-\mathbf{x} \boldsymbol{\beta}}|\boldsymbol{\theta}) and

S(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ±)=S0(teâˆ’ğ±ğ›ƒ|ğ›‰). S(t|\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\beta}, \mathbf{x}) = S_{0}(t e^{-\mathbf{x} \boldsymbol{\beta}}|\boldsymbol{\theta}).

Proportional Hazards Models

Proportional hazards (PH) models are defined as

h(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ±)=h0(t|ğ›‰)exp{ğ±ğ›ƒ}, h(t|\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\beta}, \mathbf{x}) = h_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})\exp\{\mathbf{x} \boldsymbol{\beta}\}, where h0(t|ğ›‰)h_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta}) is a baseline hazard function so that

f(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ±)=h0(t|ğ›‰)exp{ğ±ğ›ƒâˆ’H0(t|ğ›‰)eğ±ğ›ƒ}, f(t|\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\beta}, \mathbf{x}) = h_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})\exp\left\{\mathbf{x} \boldsymbol{\beta} - H_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})e^{\mathbf{x} \boldsymbol{\beta}}\right\}, and

S(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ±)=exp{âˆ’H0(t|ğ›‰)eğ±ğ›ƒ}. S(t|\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\beta}, \mathbf{x}) = \exp\left\{ - H_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})e^{\mathbf{x} \boldsymbol{\beta}}\right\}.

Proportional Odds Models

Proportional Odds (PO) models are defined as

R(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ±)=R0(t|ğ›‰)exp{ğ±ğ›ƒ}, R(t|\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\beta}, \mathbf{x}) = R_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})\exp\{\mathbf{x} \boldsymbol{\beta}\}, where R0(t|ğ›‰)=1âˆ’S0(t|ğ›‰)S0(t|ğ›‰)=exp{H0(t|ğ›‰)}âˆ’1\displaystyle R_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta}) = \frac{1-S_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})}{S_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})} = \exp\{H_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})\}-1 is a baseline odds function so that

f(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ±)=h0(t|ğ›‰)exp{ğ±ğ›ƒ+H0(t|ğ›‰)}[1+R0(t|ğ›‰)eğ±ğ›ƒ]2. f(t|\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\beta}, \mathbf{x}) = \frac{h_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})\exp\{\mathbf{x} \boldsymbol{\beta} + H_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})\}}{[1 + R_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})e^{\mathbf{x} \boldsymbol{\beta}}]^2}.

and

S(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ±)=11+R0(t|ğ›‰)eğ±ğ›ƒ. S(t|\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\beta}, \mathbf{x}) = \frac{1}{1 + R_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})e^{\mathbf{x} \boldsymbol{\beta}}}.

Accelerated Hazard Models

Accelerated hazard (AH) models can be defined as

h(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ±)=h0(t/eğ±ğ›ƒ|ğ›‰)h(t|\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\beta},\mathbf{x}) = h_{0}\left(t/e^{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\beta}}|\boldsymbol{\theta}\right)

so that

S(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ±)=exp{âˆ’H0(t/eğ±ğ›ƒ|ğ›‰)eğ±ğ›ƒ}S(t|\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\beta},\mathbf{x}) = \exp\left\{- H_{0}\left(t/ e^{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\beta}}|\boldsymbol{\theta}\right)e^{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\beta}} \right\} and f(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ±)=h0(t/eğ±ğ›ƒ|ğ›‰)exp{âˆ’H0(t/eğ±ğ›ƒ|ğ›‰)eğ±ğ›ƒ}.f(t|\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\beta}, \mathbf{x}) = h_{0}\left(t/e^{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\beta}}|\boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\exp\left\{- H_{0}\left(t/ e^{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\beta}}|\boldsymbol{\theta}\right)e^{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\beta}} \right\}.

Extended hazard Models

The survival function of the extended hazard (EH) model is given by:

S(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ›Ÿ)=exp{âˆ’H0(t/eğ±ğ›ƒ|ğ›‰)exp(ğ±(ğ›ƒ+ğ›Ÿ))}.S(t|\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{\beta}, \boldsymbol{\phi}) = \exp\left\{-H_{0}(t/e^{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\beta}}|\boldsymbol{\theta})\exp(\mathbf{x}(\boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\phi}))\right\}.

The hazard and the probability density functions are then expressed as:

h(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ›Ÿ)=h0(t/eğ±ğ›ƒ|ğ›‰)exp{ğ±ğ›Ÿ}h(t|\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{\beta}, \boldsymbol{\phi}) = h_{0}(t/e^{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\beta}}|\boldsymbol{\theta})\exp\{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\phi}\} and

f(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ›Ÿ)=h0(t/eğ±ğ›ƒ|ğ›‰)exp{ğ±ğ›ƒ}exp{âˆ’H0(t/eğ±ğ›ƒ|ğ›‰)exp(ğ±(ğ›ƒ+ğ›Ÿ))},f(t|\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{\beta}, \boldsymbol{\phi}) = h_{0}(t/e^{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\beta}}|\boldsymbol{\theta})\exp\{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\beta}\}\exp\left\{-H_{0}(t/e^{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\beta}}|\boldsymbol{\theta})\exp(\mathbf{x}(\boldsymbol{\beta}+ \boldsymbol{\phi}))\right\},

respectively.

The EH model includes the AH, AFT and PH models as particular cases when ğ›Ÿ=ğŸ\boldsymbol{\phi} = \mathbf{0}, ğ›Ÿ=âˆ’ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\phi} = -\boldsymbol{\beta}, and ğ›ƒ=ğŸ\boldsymbol{\beta} = \mathbf{0}, respectively.

Yang and Prentice Models

The survival function of the Yang and Prentice (YP) model is given by:

S(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ›Ÿ)=[1+ÎºSÎºLR0(t|ğ›‰)]âˆ’ÎºL.S(t|\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{\beta}, \boldsymbol{\phi}) = \left[1+\frac{\kappa_{S}}{\kappa_{L}}R_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]^{-\kappa_{L}}.

The hazard and the probability density functions are then expressed as:

h(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ›Ÿ)=ÎºSh0(t|ğ›‰)exp{H0(t|ğ›‰)}[1+ÎºSÎºLR0(t|ğ›‰)]h(t|\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{\beta}, \boldsymbol{\phi}) = \frac{\kappa_{S}h_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})\exp\{H_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})\}}{\left[1+\frac{\kappa_{S}}{\kappa_{L}}R_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]} and

f(t|ğ›‰,ğ›ƒ,ğ›Ÿ)=ÎºSh0(t|ğ›‰)exp{H0(t|ğ›‰)}[1+ÎºSÎºLR0(t|ğ›‰)]âˆ’(1+ÎºL),f(t|\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{\beta}, \boldsymbol{\phi}) = \kappa_{S}h_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})\exp\{H_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})\}\left[1+\frac{\kappa_{S}}{\kappa_{L}}R_{0}(t|\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]^{-(1+\kappa_{L})},

respectively, where ÎºS=exp{ğ±ğ›ƒ}\kappa_{S} = \exp\{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\beta}\} and ÎºL=exp{ğ±ğ›Ÿ}\kappa_{L} = \exp\{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\phi}\}.

The YO model includes the PH and PO models as particular cases when ğ›Ÿ=ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\phi} = \boldsymbol{\beta} and ğ›Ÿ=ğŸ\boldsymbol{\phi} = \mathbf{0}, respectively.
